title: At what age do we learn the most about who we are? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have my doubts if Man learns ever about who he is because Man, mostly the scientists use to ask: “Who are we and where are we going to and where do we come from” so and because by this doubt I don’t know if Man really knows or learns about who is he and if there will be a proper age to learn that once on every ages Man learns new things and to learn things there isn’t also a proper age to that so the question is if Man can really learn about himself and if he learns about he can do on nature and over his kindred mostly the bad things that Man is capable of. And so and because Man doesn’t know who he is, from where he comes and where does he go Man isn’t able to recognize that he is a creation from his real Creator, at his image and similitude, that is God, and not, nature and whose God is waiting for him in Heaven that is where does all men go to after their real death to Earth on their earthly body and rise up to Heaven on their form of soul to be judged by their real Creator, that is God, and not, nature.

For me it was 28–29— i became a man- who knows what others might think about that, that’s just my own feelings, id say 20 to 25–6—— 7/8/9s putting all that learning together, enough to feel like the whole over thinking over feeling things lifted, maturities about not fretting, knowing enough to not fret, too much, its a bit like a weight of thought,thinking, culminating in the finding out, the comfort in knowing, that eases the concerns in the not knowing, so a learning to know, process, that naturally when you do know, can see, without feeling an overload or any insecurities, in your thinking, we grow every day, nothings fixed anyway, often what we think today’s, gone tomorrow, and replaced with a newer updated version of understanding, its like the pictures been painted, and now its just a matter of coloring it in. i still haven’t grown up and im 64- put it that way.

I think adolescence is a time of great awakening. At least for me, I met people and engaged them in conversations and they told me about their lives. Had they perceived me as a “child” they would not have shared that information with me. By learning about other people, I came to an idea of who and what I would like to be and what I needed to do to head off in that direction.
